Award.AwardTitle: NSF Workshop on the Economics of Cloud Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Public cloud computing is rapidly becoming the foundation of our information-based economy. Users are
adopting cloud platforms in lieu of maintaining dedicated computing infrastructure primarily due to the
resulting savings in costs. Since cloud platforms earn revenue from utilizing their infrastructure by
renting it out to customers, and earn no revenue if their infrastructure is idle, their goal is to maximize
utilization. The increasing complexity of cloud markets raises new research
challenges for both users and providers that are inherently economic. This award will support the
organization of a workshop to bring together researchers from computer systems and networks and from
the fields of economics, finance, and operations research to define important research challenges at the
intersection of economics and cloud computing over the next 5-10 years.

The research agenda of the workshop has the potential for broad and transformative impact on the US and
beyond by fostering a new interdisciplinary community in this nascent area, identifying its key research
challenges, and laying the foundation for future innovations that increase the efficiency of using cloud
computing resources. Furthermore, the workshop will engage early career scholars and those from
diverse backgrounds and underrepresented groups to connect them with a broad community of academic
and industrial researchers interested in the intersection of economics and computer systems and
networking.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Public cloud platforms are becoming the foundation of our Information-based economy, providing the large-scale computing resources driving advances in many industry sectors.   A key benefit that public cloud platforms offer is ``pay-as-you-go'' pricing models where consumers pay for only the time that they use resources and services. Pay-as-you-go pricing models for cloud resources and services are attractive, since they enable consumers to convert high upfront capital expenses, e.g., for physical space and hardware, into recurring operating expenses, which are often less than the capital expenses, especially when hardware is not operated near full utilization.  The potential for lower costs, ease of use, and the ability to scale resource usage up and down quickly, continues to drive growth in cloud platforms along multiple dimensions, including their size, number and type of offerings, and pricing models.   However, the increasing size and complexity of the cloud, combined with new considerations consumers and providers must make over cost, pricing models, and SLOs, raises new research challenges for cloud consumers and providers that are inherently economic.    Increasingly, these economic considerations are directly affecting cloud platform and application design. 


To address this problem, the National Science Foundation's (NSF) organized the "Workshop on Cloud Economics" to identify key research challenges over the next 5-10 years in cloud computing that lie at the intersection of computing and economics. The workshop brought together and solicited feedback from participants with a variety of backgrounds, including in computer systems, algorithms, game theory, economics, and operations research, working in academia and industry. The workshop included discussions along 4 broad themes: i) Cloud Pricing Models and Incentives, ii) Cost Optimization, iii) Cloud Competition, and iv) Emerging Issues. In identifying research challenges in these areas, the workshop participants emphasized that i) cloud applications must consider cost when making resource and service allocation decisions, and that cost considerations are directly impacting application design, e.g., the choice of resources and services that form the application, and while approaches from classical economics and operations research can (and are) being adapted to more efficiently operate and use cloud platforms, cloud resources and the behavior of their users are different enough from other commodity markets to also motivate fundamentally novel research in these areas. The workshop report presents findings from the discussions. 


The workshop details and discussion materials are available at: https://umass-sustainablecomputinglab.github.io/nsfw/
